It is not uncommon for children to report overconfidence about accomplishing difficult tasks. Even being provided with feedback indicating low performance may not decrease self-efficacy. The incongruence between children's self-efficacy and their actual performance can arise when children lack task familiarity and do not fully understand what is required to execute a task successfully. As they gain experience, their accuracy improves. Children may also be unduly swayed by certain task features and decide based on these that they can or cannot perform the task. In subtraction, for example, children may focus on how many numbers or columns (the problem contain and judge problems with fewer columns as less difficult than those with more columns,) even when the former are conceptually more difficult. This is an instance where higher self-efficacy is problematic because students feel unrealistically overconfident and not motivated to seek help and improve their skills. As children's capability to focus on multiple features improves, so does their accuracy.

There is little hope of finding high grade sources of minerals other than those we know already. The planet's crust has been thoroughly explored and digging deeper is not likely to help, since ores form mainly because of hydrothermal processes that operate near the surface. The oceanic floor is geologically too recent for containing ores; only the sea floor near the continents could be a useful source of minerals. The oceans themselves contain metal ions, but extracting rare metals from seawater is out of question because of their minute concentrations that make the process highly expensive in energy terms. In addition, the amounts dissolved are not very large. For instance, considering the concentration of copper in the oceans, we can calculate that the total amount dissolved corresponds to 10 years of the present mine production. Some suggest outer space as a source of minerals but the energy cost of leaving earth is a major barrier. Then, most bodies of the solar systems — e.g., the Moon and the asteroids — are geochemically "dead" and contain no ores.

When we apply a simple technological solution to a problem that is actually nested within a complex biological system, we cannot easily predict how the system will adapt to the technology. In fact, if we don't understand how the "problem" is linked to or supported by the ecosystem, then we are defining the problem in human terms without understanding its biological or ecological foundation. For example, we have used synthetic pesticides to control unwanted insect pests in agriculture since the late 1940s. Each and every pesticide that has been in common and widespread use has resulted in the evolution of resistant pest species, and this has resulted in a constant search for replacement pesticides as a countermeasure. This back and forth battle to control a biological problem with a technological solution has no ending point and is the result of an unwillingness on the human side to recognize the underlying issue.

Psychiatry is often viewed as medicine's 'poor cousin', and there are good reasons for this. During the past century, our understanding of bodily mechanisms has advanced through scientific understanding on a whole number of different fronts and led to important new drug treatments in areas as diverse as cardiology, cancer therapy, and treatment of bacterial and viral infections. However, our understanding of how the human brain works as a whole still remains far from clear, and as a consequence, drug treatments for mental disorders have often been far from inspiring, with even the mechanisms of action of those drugs that do seem to have a positive impact on mental health remaining obscure. This lack of clarity is due to the brain being so much more complex than any other organ in the body, but it also reflects a central theme of this book, namely that human conscious awareness is as much a social as a biological entity, and therefore human mental disorders have a major social input.

When our brains encounter something unfamiliar or potentially dangerous, we quickly pivot to fight-or-flight response, in which all of our mental (and sometimes physical) energy is devoted to addressing the perceived threat. Researchers at Harvard Medical School have done extensive research into this response and found that when faced with information that feels unknown or threatening, our brains send out a distress signal to the rest of the body through the autonomic nervous system, "which controls such involuntary body functions as breathing, blood pressure, heartbeat, and the dilation or constriction of key blood vessels and small airways." These physical responses can be uncomfortable or even painful, but more importantly they then trigger emotions that end up guiding our decision-making. We all know what it's like to shake our heads and think, "I'd be so much smarter than that," while watching the main character in a horror movie make a bafflingly terrible decision in the face of extreme danger. Chances are, however, we wouldn't be smarter. In fight-or-flight mode, the part of our brain that takes over is only horror-movie-level smart, which isn't very smart at all.

Cambridge biologist William Hamilton studied the social behaviour of ants and wondered to himself not only why they often sacrificed themselves for their nestmates, but also how it was that sterile worker ants might have arisen, given these females don't breed but rather leave this to the queen. Hamilton solved this problem when he realised that, due to their particular method of breeding, these sterile worker ants share 75 per cent of their genes with their sisters. Hamilton then began to consider a 'gene's eye view' of natural selection, and immediately realised such non-queen worker ants could actually pass on a larger proportion of their genes indirectly by, instead of breeding themselves, helping to raise their younger sisters. For each sister raised, they are passing on 75 per cent of their genes rather than the 50 per cent that would be passed on via normal sexual reproduction. To Hamilton, ant colonies should really be perceived as a form of extended family where the genetic interests of all are served by the apparent altruistic behaviour of some.

The most common justification for a move to autonomous vehicles could well be called the argument from safety: the implementation of driving automation systems will reduce the risk of death or injury from automobile accidents. The basic premise seems reasonable enough: humans behind the wheel can be unreliable and, all too often, distracted, fatigued, or otherwise impaired. This fallibility of human drivers no doubt contributes to a rate of injury and fatality that, in other contexts, would be considered a public health crisis. Driving automation systems, by contrast, are supposed to be more reliable and, depending on the overall prevalence of autonomous vehicles and of the infrastructure to support them, may be able to coordinate with other vehicles to avoid collisions and other mishaps. On these premises, and assuming the new technology functions as advertised, it only makes sense to swap out an unstable and unreliable human control system for something demonstrably better.

Most students can provide numerous examples of common sense, such as never putting a fork into an electrical outlet, not sticking your tongue on a pole covered with ice or placing your hands in boiling water, avoiding looking directly into the sun, and not attempting to attend a state dinner at the White House without an invitation And yet, none of these examples of common sense represents knowledge that we were born with; instead, we have learned all these things. The sociological perspective emphasizes that knowledge is gained through trial and error, experience, and the influences of others in the social environment. Experience teaches us to act routinely in most social situations. Before long, such expectations come to be viewed as common sense. However, because each of us has unique social experiences, we come to view common sense differently — we see it from our unique perspective. Thus, if one has not been exposed to a particular behavior labeled by some as commonsense knowledge — one is not capable of acting in an obvious, or routine, manner.

But a study from the University of Florida has found that something magical happens when the teacher takes a little more time — just three seconds — to wait to pick a child, and then for the child to think about the response. The most immediate benefit was seen in the length of the children's answers. ② <u>The small amount of thinking time meant that the children spent between three and seven times as long to elaborate their thoughts, including more evidence for their viewpoint and a greater consideration of alternative theories</u>. The increased waiting time also encouraged the children to listen to each other's opinions and develop their ideas. Encouragingly, their more sophisticated thinking also translated to their writing, which became more nuanced and complex. That's an astonishing improvement from the simple act of exercising teacherly patience. As the researcher Mary Budd Rowe put it in her original paper: "slowing down may be a way of speeding up."

The most common justification for a move to autonomous vehicles could well be called the argument from safety: the implementation of driving automation systems will reduce the risk of death or injury from automobile accidents. The basic premise seems reasonable enough: humans behind the wheel can be unreliable and, all too often, distracted, fatigued, or otherwise impaired. This fallibility of human drivers no doubt contributes to a rate of injury and fatality that, in other contexts, would be considered a public health crisis. Driving automation systems, by contrast, are supposed to be more reliable and, depending on the overall prevalence of autonomous vehicles and of the infrastructure to support them, may be able to coordinate with other vehicles to avoid collisions and other mishaps. On these premises, and assuming the new technology functions as advertised, it only makes sense to __________ for something demonstrably better.

Having asked the class a question, the average American teacher typically waits less than a second before picking a child to provide an answer — sending out a strong message that speed is valued over complex thinking. But a study from the University of Florida has found that something magical happens when the teacher takes a little more time — just three seconds — to wait to pick a child, and then for the child to think about the response. The most immediate benefit was seen in the __________. The small amount of thinking time meant that the children spent between three and seven times as long elaborating their thoughts, including more evidence for their viewpoint and a greater consideration of alternative theories. The increased waiting time also encouraged the children to listen to each other's opinions and develop their ideas. Encouragingly, their more sophisticated thinking also translated to their writing, which became more nuanced and complex. That's an astonishing improvement from the simple act of exercising teacherly patience. As the researcher Mary Budd Rowe put it in her original paper: "slowing down may be a way of speeding up."

There were incremental improvements from the fifteenth century onwards involving more comfortable coaches and, in the eighteenth century, greatly improved roads, at least in Britain if not everywhere in Europe. Cambridge biologist William Hamilton studied the social behaviour of ants and wondered to himself not only why they often sacrificed themselves for their nestmates, but also how it was that sterile worker ants might have arisen, given these females don't breed but rather leave this to the queen. Hamilton solved this problem when he realised that, due to their particular method of breeding, these sterile worker ants share 75 per cent of their genes with their sisters. Hamilton then began to consider a 'gene's eye view' of natural selection, and immediately realised such non-queen worker ants could actually pass on a larger proportion of their genes indirectly by, instead of breeding themselves, helping to raise their younger sisters. For each sister raised, they are passing on 75 per cent of their genes rather than the 50 per cent that would be passed on via normal sexual reproduction. To Hamilton, ant colonies should really be perceived as a form of extended family where the genetic interests of all are served by the __________.

It is not uncommon for children to report overconfidence about accomplishing difficult tasks. Even being provided with feedback indicating low performance may not decrease self-efficacy. The incongruence between children's self-efficacy and their actual performance can arise when children lack task familiarity and do not fully understand what is required to execute a task successfully. As they gain experience, their accuracy improves. Children may also be unduly swayed by certain task features and decide based on these that they can or cannot perform the task. In subtraction, for example, children may focus on how many numbers or columns (the problem contain and judge problems with fewer columns as less difficult than those with more columns,) even when the former are conceptually more difficult. This is an instance where higher self-efficacy is problematic because students feel unrealistically overconfident and not motivated to seek help and improve their skills. As children's capability to focus on multiple features improves, so does their accuracy.

Having asked the class a question, the average American teacher typically waits less than a second before picking a child to provide an answer — sending out a strong message that speed is valued over complex thinking. But a study from the University of Florida has found that something magical happens when the teacher takes a little more time — just three seconds — to wait to pick a child, and then for the child to think about the response. The most immediate benefit was seen in the length of the children's answers. The small amount of thinking time meant that the children spent between three and seven times as long elaborating their thoughts, including more evidence for their viewpoint and a greater consideration of alternative theories. The increased waiting time also encouraged the children to listen to each other's opinions and develop their ideas. Encouragingly, their more sophisticated thinking also translated to their writing, which became more nuanced and complex. That's an astonishing improvement from the simple act of exercising teacherly patience. As the researcher Mary Budd Rowe put it in her original paper: "slowing down may be a way of speeding up."

There is little hope of finding high grade sources of minerals other than those we know already. The planet's crust has been thoroughly explored and digging deeper is not likely to help, since ores form mainly because of hydrothermal processes that operate near the surface. The oceanic floor is geologically too recent for containing ores; only the sea floor near the continents could be a useful source of minerals. The oceans themselves contain metal ions, but extracting rare metals from seawater is out of question because of their minute concentrations that make the process highly expensive in energy terms. In addition, the amounts dissolved are not very large. For instance, considering the concentration of copper in the oceans, we can calculate that the total amount dissolved corresponds to 10 years of the present mine production. Some suggest outer space as a source of minerals but the energy cost of leaving earth is a major barrier. Then, most bodies of the solar systems ― e.g., the Moon and the asteroids ― are geochemically "dead" and contain no ores.

When we apply a simple technological solution to a problem that is actually nested within a complex biological system, we cannot easily predict how the system will adapt to the technology. In fact, if we don't understand how the "problem" is linked to or supported by the ecosystem, then we are defining the problem in human terms without understanding its biological or ecological foundation. For example, we have used synthetic pesticides to control unwanted insect pests in agriculture since the late 1940s. Each and every pesticide that has been in common and widespread use has resulted in the evolution of resistant pest species, and this has resulted in a constant search for replacement pesticides as a countermeasure. This back and forth battle to control a biological problem with a technological solution has no ending point and is the result of an unwillingness on the human side to recognize the underlying issue.

During the past century, our understanding of bodily mechanisms has advanced through scientific understanding on a whole number of different fronts and led to important new drug treatments in areas as diverse as cardiology, cancer therapy, and treatment of bacterial and viral infections. Cambridge biologist William Hamilton studied the social behaviour of ants and wondered to himself not only why they often sacrificed themselves for their nestmates, but also how it was that sterile worker ants might have arisen, given these females don't breed but rather leave this to the queen. Hamilton solved this problem when he realised that, due to their particular method of breeding, these sterile worker ants share 75 per cent of their genes with their sisters. Hamilton then began to consider a 'gene's eye view' of natural selection, and immediately realised such non-queen worker ants could actually pass on a larger proportion of their genes indirectly by, instead of breeding themselves, helping to raise their younger sisters. For each sister raised, they are passing on 75 per cent of their genes rather than the 50 per cent that would be passed on via normal sexual reproduction. To Hamilton, ant colonies should really be perceived as a form of extended family where the genetic interests of all are served by the apparent altruistic behaviour of some.

When our brains encounter something unfamiliar or potentially dangerous, we quickly pivot to fight-or-flight response, in which all of our mental (and sometimes physical) energy is devoted to addressing the perceived threat. Researchers at Harvard Medical School have done extensive research into this response and found that when faced with information that feels unknown or threatening, our brains send out a distress signal to the rest of the body through the autonomic nervous system, "which controls such involuntary body functions as breathing, blood pressure, heartbeat, and the dilation or constriction of key blood vessels and small airways." These physical responses can be uncomfortable or even painful, but more importantly they then trigger emotions that end up guiding our decision-making. We all know what it's like to shake our heads and think, "I'd be so much smarter than that," while watching the main character in a horror movie make a bafflingly terrible decision in the face of extreme danger. Chances are, however, we wouldn't be smarter. In fight-or-flight mode, the part of our brain that takes over is only horror-movie-level smart, which isn't very smart at all.

One of the key constraints on the development of sports tourism prior to the nineteenth century was the lack of suitable transport. There were incremental improvements from the fifteenth century onwards involving more comfortable coaches and, in the eighteenth century, greatly improved roads, at least in Britain if not everywhere in Europe. But transport was primarily slow and costly. For example, the journey time from London to Bath in 1680, a distance of 107 miles, was around sixty hours. Vastly improved roads had cut this time to ten hours by 1800 , but the time and cost still meant that only the wealthy in society could travel substantial distances. It was not until the development of the railways in the nineteenth century that a relatively cheap and efficient form of transport was afforded to the population at large, enabling sports tourism to develop beyond the small and exclusive upper class activity that had existed hitherto. As Vamplew points out, the railways 'revolutionized sport in England by widening the catchment area for spectators and by enabling participants to compete nationally'.

The most common justification for a move to autonomous vehicles could well be called the argument from safety: the implementation of driving automation systems will reduce the risk of death or injury from automobile accidents. The basic premise seems reasonable enough: humans behind the wheel can be unreliable and, all too often, distracted, fatigued, or otherwise impaired. This fallibility of human drivers no doubt contributes to a rate of injury and fatality that, in other contexts, would be considered a public health crisis. Driving automation systems, by contrast, are supposed to be more reliable and, depending on the overall prevalence of autonomous vehicles and of the infrastructure to support them, may be able to coordinate with other vehicles to avoid collisions and other mishaps. On these premises, and assuming the new technology functions as advertised, it only makes sense to swap out an unstable and unreliable human control system for something demonstrably better.

Most students can provide numerous examples of common sense, such as never putting a fork into an electrical outlet, not sticking your tongue on a pole covered with ice or placing your hands in boiling water, avoiding looking directly into the sun, and not attempting to attend a state dinner at the White House without an invitation. And yet, none of these examples of common sense represents knowledge that we were born with; instead, we have learned all these things. The sociological perspective emphasizes that knowledge is gained through trial and error, experience, and the influences of others in the social environment. Experience teaches us to act routinely in most social situations. Before long, such expectations come to be viewed as common sense. However, because each of us has unique social experiences, we come to view common sense differently — we see it from our unique perspective. Thus, if one has not been exposed to a particular behavior - labeled by some as commonsense knowledge — one is not capable of acting in an obvious, or routine, manner.

정답 및 해설
1) 3 [아이들의 과도한 자신감이 실제 수행과 불일치하며, 과제에 대한 경험 부족과 단순한 표면 특징에만 의존하는 경향 때문에 생긴다는 내용을 중심으로 하고 있으며 이를 가장 잘 반영하는 제목은 "Children's Overconfidence and Learning Accuracy"이다.]
2) 5 [지구와 바다, 우주 어디를 보아도 새로운 고농도의 광물 자원을 찾을 가능성이 매우 낮다는 주장을 일관되게 펼치고 있다. 따라서 "The Limited Prospects of Discovering New Mineral Sources"가 제목으로 가장 적절하다.]
3) 5 [단순한 기술적 해결책이 복잡한 생태계에 어떤 예기치 못한 결과를 초래하는지에 대해 설명하고 있으며 특히 해충을 죽이기 위한 살충제 사용이 결국 내성을 가진 해충을 진화시키며 악순환을 만든다는 점을 지적하고 있다. 따라서 "The Risk of Applying Simple Technology to Complex Systems"가 가장 적절한 제목이다.]
4) 4 [글의 핵심은 정신의학이 다른 의학 분야보다 덜 발전한 이유와 그 배경을 설명하는 데 있다. 특히 본문에서는 뇌의 복잡성과 인간의 의식이 생물학뿐 아니라 사회적 요소와도 밀접하게 연결되어 있다는 점이 강조되며 이것이 정신의학의 발전이 더딘 이유로 제시된다. 따라서 "Psychiatry's Struggles in the Shadow of Other Medical Fields"가 글 전체 내용을 가장 잘 요약한 제목이다.]
5) 5 [글의 핵심은 낯설거나 위협적인 정보를 마주했을 때 우리의 뇌가 자동으로 투쟁-도피 반응(fight-or-flight response)을 유발하며 이로 인해 합리적인 판단보다는 감정에 따라 행동하게 된다는 데 있다. 따라서 이 글은 위험 상황에서 인간의 판단력이 왜 떨어지는가에 대한 생물학적 설명을 제공하며 "Why Fear Makes Us Think Like Horror Movie Characters"가 글의 내용을 가장 잘 요약한 제목이다.]
6) 3 [글의 핵심은 생물학자 윌리엄 해밀턴이 개미의 이타적 행동을 유전자의 관점에서 설명한 방식에 있으며 글을 통해 해밀턴은 자연선택을 개체가 아닌 유전자 중심으로 바라보는 새로운 관점을 제시하고 개미 집단을 유전적 이익을 공유하는 확장된 가족으로 해석한다. 따라서 "How Genes Shape Ant Altruism"이 글 전체 내용을 가장 잘 요약한 제목이다.]
7) 5 [자율주행차 도입의 가장 일반적인 정당화 근거가 안전성 향상에 있다는 점을 설명하는 글이다. 인간 운전자는 피로, 산만함, 판단 실수 등의 요인으로 인해 사고를 일으키기 쉬운 반면 자율주행 시스템은 보다 신뢰할 수 있으며 차량 간 협업까지 가능해 사고율을 크게 줄일 수 있다는 주장이다. 따라서 "Why Replacing Human Drivers Might Be the Safer Option"이 글의 내용을 가장 잘 요약한 제목이다.]

8) 3 [상식(common sense)이 선천적인 것이 아니라 사회 적 경험을 통해 후천적으로 습득되는 것임을 강조하는 글 이다. 사람들은 반복되는 경험과 타인의 영향 속에서 특정 행동이 당연하다고 여기는 습관을 형성하지만 각자의 사회 적 배경이다르기 때문에 상식이라 여기는 내용도 서로 다 를 수 있다고 글에서는 말하고 있다. 따라서 "Why Common Sense Isn't the Same for Everyone"이 글 전체를 가장 잘 요약한 제목이다.]
9) (1) which $\rightarrow$ that ["a strong message"와 "speed is valued over complex thinking"은 동격 관계이므로 which가 아닌 접속사 that을 써야 한다.] (2) to elaborate $\rightarrow$ elaborating ["spend + 시간 또는 돈 + v-ing", 따라서 elaborating이 되어야 한다.]
10) (2) used $\rightarrow$ have used ["since the late 1940s"는 특정 시점부터 지금까지의 지속적인 행위를 말하므로 현재완료 시제를 사용하는 것이 일반적이다. 따라서 used가 아닌 have used를 써야 한다.]
11) (1) remaining $\rightarrow$ remains ["our understanding of how the human brain works as a whole"이 문장 전체의 주어이므로 동사 역할을 할 수 있는 remains가 와야 한다. 주어가 길어지거나 각종 수식어구가 주어 뒤에 들어가는 경우 동사가 들어갈 자리에 v -ing를 넣어서 오답을 유도하는 어법 문제가 많으므로 주의해야 한다.]
12) (2) allowing $\rightarrow$ allows ["AI"가 문장 전체의 주어, "with its ability to process vast amounts of data in real time"은 삽입구이므로 동사 역할을 할 수 있는 allows가 와야 한다. 11번 문제 해설 참고]
13) (2) afforded $\rightarrow$ was afforded [it-that 강조구문과 not until A until B(A하고 나서야 B하다) 구문을 사용한 문장이며 that절은 "the population at large afforded a relatively cheap and efficient form of transport" (대중은 상대적으로 저렴하고 효율적인 교통이 이용 가능했다)가 수동태로 바뀐 형태이다. 따라서 afforded가 아닌 was afforded가 되어야 한다.]
14) (3) different $\rightarrow$ differently [동사 view를 수식하므로 부사인 differently가 되어야 한다.]
15) (4) [예시 부분으로, 아이들은 뺄셈에서 얼마나 많은 숫자와 열이 있는지에 집중하기 때문에 더 적은 열이 있는 문제를 덜 어려운 것으로 판단한다는 내용이다. 따라서 fewer를 more로 바꿔야 한다.]
16) (2) [교사가 질문 후 3 초만 기다려도 학생들은 더 길고 복잡한 답을 하며, 타인의 의견을 듣고 사고를 확장하는 태도와 글쓰기 능력까지 향상되는 긍정적인 효과가 나타난다는 내용의 글이다. 따라서 2번의 speed를 length로 바꿔야 한다. 3번의 motivated는 본문에는 encouraged로, 4번의 elaborated는 sophisticated로 되어 있다.]

annotations.html: 인간이 단순한 기술적 해결책을 생태학적 복잡성이 얽힌 문제에 적용할 때 발생하는 예측 불가능성을 강조하는 내용의 지문이다. 특히 해충 방제를 위해 합성 농약을 사용했지만 해충이 저항성을 갖게 되면서 끊임없는 대체 농약 개발이 필요해졌다는 사례를 통해 자연 시스템이 기술에 어떻게 적응할지는 쉽게 예측할 수 없음을 보여준다. 따라서 "forecast easily how the system will adapt"가 빈칸에 가장 적절하다. 본문에는 "easily predict how the system adapt to the technology"로 되어 있다. 4번 "predict the long-term effects of chemicals"는 화학물질의 장기적인 영향에만 국한되어 있고 생태계 전체 시스템의 반응(adaptation)이라는 보다 넓은 맥락을 포착하지 못하므로 정답과는 다소 거리가 있다.
